title: Bill Belichick explains ‘simple’ reason why he decided to ban Patriots scout at UNC
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick banned a Patriots scout from UNC practices due to a strained relationship with his former team.
Belichick cited feeling unwelcome at the Patriots as the reason for denying them access to UNC facilities.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel acknowledged Belichick's decision, emphasizing the need to find alternate scouting methods.

title: Patriots 7, Raiders 7 (2nd):  Maye hits Douglas for 1st TD of season
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Drake Maye connects with Douglas for a 3-yard touchdown, leveling the score 7-7 against the Raiders.
Kayshon Boutte records 4 catches for 74 yards in the Patriots' opening game at Gillette Stadium.
Jaylinn Hawkins intercepts a pass for the Patriots, recovering from an earlier 26-yard touchdown allowed to Tre Tucker.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Dropkick Murphys frontman Ken Casey criticized Trump during their Seisiún festival performance at Suffolk Downs in Boston.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a Marine veteran and oyster farmer from Maine, who is running against GOP Sen. Susan Collins.
Platner, 40, aims to challenge Trumpism and is critical of the Democratic establishment, as noted in a Boston Globe opinion column.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu's program converted five office floors into 15 apartments at 281 Franklin St in downtown Boston.
The residential conversion program, started in October 2023, received $15 million in state funding in June 2024.
Developer Adam Burns' project faced slow progress due to high office vacancy rates needing more resources and strategic planning.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Harvard disciplinary cases tripled in 2023-24 due to student involvement in pro-Palestine protests, the Harvard Crimson reported.
Half of the disciplined students violated protest policies during a November 2023 occupation and an April-May 2024 encampment.
Five students initially suspended had penalties reduced to probation; tensions eased as protests decreased in frequency.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: Seisiún Irish music festival kicked off despite severe weather, featuring performances by Dropkick Murphys and Holy Locust at Suffolk Downs.
Attendees experienced a rain delay but returned to enjoy sets by bands like The Hold Steady and The Scratch.
Guinness was served to festival-goers, who wore Irish-themed attire in support of the diverse lineup of Irish music.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective exhibit at Bates College showcases 149 artworks, including illustrations and satirical drawings.
Anecdote shared about Hunter S. Thompson and Steadman's 1970 escapade in Newport involving psilocybin and yacht spray-painting.
Exhibit features Steadman's collaborations with Thompson and other notable artworks, available until October 11 in Lewiston, Maine.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: About 40,000 Boston-area adults risk losing SNAP benefits under Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill, a report reveals.
The bill impacts 9,600 legally present immigrants in Massachusetts, who may lose SNAP eligibility due to new requirements.
Massachusetts' SNAP administrative costs would rise to $175 million, with the state covering 75% under the new bill.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: The Revolution lost 3-2 to the Chicago Fire, hurting their playoff chances significantly.
Peyton Miller scored at 17 years old, followed by a stoppage-time Carles Gil penalty, closing the final gap.
Revolution coach Caleb Porter acknowledged strategic failures, taking responsibility for poor playoff prospects.

title: Boston’s preliminary election is almost here. Here’s who will be on the ballot
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's preliminary election on Sept. 9 narrows the field for the mayoral race and City Council seats.
Ten candidates are competing for four at-large City Council positions, with eight advancing to the general election.
Mayor Michelle Wu faces challenges from Josh Kraft, Robert Cappucci, and Domingos DaRosa in the mayoral race.
